awd_titl_txt: Investigating the Forces that Transduce Mechanical Cues to Branching Neurons
awd_abstract_narration:
Neurons, the basic cells of nerves, are one of the most difficult to regenerate after disease or injury. If advances are going to be made in engineering systems that support nerve regrowth and regeneration, it is imperative that we develop a full understanding of how these cells respond to their biomechanical environment. This study will investigate how changes in the extracellular mechanical environment affects the development of neurons and the branching of dendrite -- the structure that receives signals from other nerve cells. Knowledge gained from this project will help to develop strategies that may eventually improve treatments for degenerative neural diseases or following nerve injury due to trauma. The research team will integrate students at all levels, from graduate school through high school, as well as teachers into the project. In addition, outreach will involve the development of hands-on projects and demonstrations that can introduce the public to concepts of neuroscience, imaging, and biomechanics. 

Two hypotheses are being investigated related to neuron growth and development within this project. The first is that local structural changes associated with applied cell forces act to transduce extracellular mechanical cues to the cytoskeleton. The second is that local changes in cellular tension in response to changes in the extracellular mechanical microenvironment act to transduce extracellular mechanical cues to the cytoskeleton. The research team will make use of a vinculin force sensor for which the tension can be measured using Forster resonance energy transfer (FRET). This mechanical measurement will be combined with fluorescence imaging of the cytoskeletal dynamics. Thus, the specific aims of this project are to: 1) demonstrate that vinculin expression changes as a function of substrate stiffness and tension; 2) demonstrate that vinculin tension is altered in response to changes in substrate stiffness and investigate the role of integrin, cadherin, and neurotransmitter receptors in mediating this response; and 3) investigate the relationship between vinculin tension, microtubule assembly, and the resulting dendritic branching.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
While physical forces are emerging as an important determinant of cellular function, the role of mechanical forces underlying dendritic branching in neurons is still poorly understood. In epithelial cells, vinculin, a protein involved in cellular attachment to the extra-cellular matrix or other cells, is recruited to form stable adhesions and is under tension at these adhesion sites.  However, less is known about the function of vinculin in dendritic branching of neurons. Thus, the goal of this project is to investigate the expression and function of vinculin to investigate how mechanical cues, such as substrate stiffness, are transduced to developing neurons.  To probe vinculin tension within neurons, we utilize the vinculin tension sensor, VinTS. VinTS reports on tension across vinculin that can be quantified by a microscopy technique based on measuring Forster resonance energy transfer (FRET) between two fluorescent proteins connected by an elastic linker. Another aim of this project is to advance and simplify the measurement of FRET efficiency. 

  • Intellectual Merit:

Our experiments revealed that the distribution of vinculin within the dendrites and growth cones of neurons is not uniform and highly variable.  This lack of a well-defined pattern of vinculin expression has prevented us from arriving at clear conclusions regarding the precise function of vinculin in neuronal dendrites and its response to mechanical cues.  However, consistent with this, our data show that vinculin is under low tension at the growth cones of cortical neurons, suggesting that neurons, unlike epithelial cells, do not form stable adhesions when cultured on two-dimensional glass substrates.  Our studies of vinculin tension at branch points suggest that VinTS FRET is higher than control values when neurons are cultured on 2kPa substrates compared with glass (stiffness of 10 million kPa) or with softer substrate with an elastic modulus of 0.5kPa.  Additional work is needed to explain if the higher FRET efficiency measurement could be due to increased vinculin confinement within the branch point. When immunofluorescent staining of vinculin and microtubule-associated protein 2 (MAP2) was observed as a function of day-in-culture, vinculin and MAP2, a dendritic marker, were rarely present in the same neurons, suggesting that vinculin and MAP2 may be expressed at different timepoints during the maturation of neurons in vitro.  While this and other hypotheses generated by this project remain to be fully investigated, our data raise new questions about the function of vinculin in developing neurons.

  • Broader impacts:

This is the first study investigating VinTS in neurons and provides a basis for future work involving the use of this molecular tension sensor in neuronal cells.  Advancements in methods to measure FRET efficiency include simplification of instrument calibration techniques.  The validity of a simple measurement of phase lifetime, achieved with a cost-effective confocal frequency-domain fluorescence lifetime microscope, was demonstrated to quantify accurately FRET efficiency in three-dimensional tissue models.  Finally, in a new research direction initiated by this project, instrumentation is being developed with the aim of combining fluorescence microscopy of tension sensors with optical tweezers to facilitate the study of mechanobiology.  These technological developments can benefit other fields of study involving applications of FRET biosensors.

This project supported the interdisciplinary training of students preparing for careers in bioengineering, biotechnology or the life sciences. Five undergraduates, three master’s level students, two doctoral level students, four summer interns, one international visiting scholar, and four high school summer volunteers were involved in this project.  The research was featured as part of K-12 STEM diversity programs. The PI hosted youths and staff from the 4-H Program of Rutgers Cooperative Extension of Mercer County and Somerset County. The topics of FRET and fluorescence lifetime microscopy were incorporated into two standing academic courses on bioimaging taught by the PI in the department of Biomedical Engineering at Rutgers.

 


Last Modified: 01/10/2024
Modified by: Nada N Boustany
